item.title: 'Thank you, Mr President': Hunter Biden pens letter to father Joe
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Biden will get $413,000 pension every year after retirement, more than what he makes now
item.description: US President Joe Biden will get $413,000 a year as pension after his retirement which is slightly more than the $400,000 that he currently makes as the president, a calculation by analysts at the National Taxpayers' Union revealed. Biden has a net worth of around $10 million. The pension amount would be on the top of any other money that Biden would make during his retirement.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Hunter Biden withdraws 'revenge porn' lawsuit against Fox News
item.description: Hunter Biden withdrew his lawsuit against Fox News over nude images in a 2022 series as Joe Biden ended his re-election bid. Rupert Murdoch’s Fox Nation fictionalized Hunter's trial for corruption, with no legal backing. The show was removed after an April 2024 letter; withdrawal reasons were not specified in the court filing.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Not expecting to be accepted everywhere': This NY teen has been accepted to all Ivy leagues and 20 other colleges
item.description: Malena Galletto, a teenager from Washington Heights and a recent Bronx Science High School graduate with a 97% GPA, has been accepted to all eight Ivy League schools and all 20 other colleges she applied to. Galletto received her first acceptance from the University of Albany and continued to receive acceptances from prestigious institutions, including Harvard University, where she plans to double major in government and physics.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Young NY pilot dies in plane accident. She did this 30 minutes before crash
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: 'Biden's endorsement of Kamala is his F*** you to all who...'
item.description: After Joe Biden on Sunday evening announced his decision to withdraw from the presidential election race and showed support for the nomination of Vice President Kamala Harris, a major Biden donor John Morgan said he would not fundraise for Kamala as Kamala has no chance to win against Donald Trump, he said. "Joe Biden's endorsement of Kamala is his f*** you to all who pushed him out. Be careful what you wish for," John Morgan posted on X.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Biden's decision to leave race was made in 48 hours. What happened inside? 10 points
item.description: ​US President Joe Biden tested positive for Covid on July 17 and four days later, he announced that he would withdraw from the presidential race in the "best interest" of the party and the country. Biden said he would speak to the nation later this week with more details about the decision.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Shortest marriage ever: Kuwaiti couple divorces just 3 minutes after wedding
item.description: A Kuwaiti couple's marriage ended in just 3 minutes due to groom insulting bride. Social media supports bride's decision to divorce. Model Emily Ratajkowski talks openly about divorce stigma. Story highlights the significance of respect in relationships.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: George Soros backs Kamala Harris as other Wall Street Democrats want a contest
item.description: Within hours of Joe Biden's decision to withdraw from the presidential race, prominent Democratic figures, including Hillary Clinton, Gavin Newsom, and megadonor George Soros, quickly endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as the new candidate. However, some key Democratic donors are questioning this swift move. They argue that an open convention next month in Chicago would generate voter excitement and provide a high-profile platform for Democratic policies.

item.title: How Joe Biden can unleash 'Dark Brandon' and help defeat Donald Trump
item.description: US President Joe Biden abandoned his reelection bid on Sunday under growing pressure from his fellow Democrats and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris as the party's candidate to face Republican Donald Trump in the November election. Biden, who at 81 is the oldest person ever to have occupied the Oval Office, said he would remain in the presidency until his term ended on January 20, 2025.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: UAE jails 57 Bangladeshis for protesting against Sheikh Hasina govt
item.description: A UAE court has sentenced 57 Bangladeshi citizens to lengthy prison terms for protesting against the Sheikh Hasina government over a controversial quota decision. The demonstrations were deemed unauthorized as protests are banned in the Gulf country. The protests, which embroiled Bangladesh in deadly clashes, resulted in the death of over 100 people. Meanwhile, a Bangladeshi student leader on Monday called for a 48-hour halt to the protests against the quota decision.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Lotus to Potus: Focus shifting the Kamala's running mate
item.description: Following Kamala Harris' potential candidacy for president, attention has turned to her possible running mate. Democratic operatives are considering at least six governors, lawmakers, and cabinet officials. Key names include governors Gretchen Whitmer (Michigan), Josh Shapiro (Pennsylvania), and Roy Cooper (North Carolina), along with Gavin Newsom (California), JD Pritzker (Illinois), Andy Beshear (Kentucky), and Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg. Arizona Senator Mark Kelly is also a notable contender. Speculative suggestions like Hillary Clinton, Michelle Obama, and Oprah Winfrey are deemed unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Chidanand Rajghatta

item.title: Biden drops out: Kamala Harris blooms, says will earn nomination as challengers emerge
item.description: US Vice President Kamala Harris announced her intention to earn and win the Democratic Party nomination for the presidency, with endorsements from key figures like President Biden, Hillary and Bill Clinton, and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Despite this support, challenges arose from author Marianne Williamson and Senator Joe Manchin. Former President Barack Obama refrained from endorsing Harris, suggesting the possibility of an open convention instead.
item.dc:creator: Chidanand Rajghatta
